instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2879: What is 820-2879? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.ADAPTER_SENSE: What is ADAPTER_SENSE? This is a line between the onewire circuit and the magsafe charger where the magsafe charger can talk to the SMC(system management controller) on the SYS_ONEWIRE line..
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.SMC_BC_ACOK: What is SMC_BC_ACOK? This is identical to CHGR_ACOK. This will come out of the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging chip when CHGR_ACIN & CHGR_DCIN are present, and is necessary for the onewire circuit to begin working. On most Macbooks, CHGR_ACOK needs to be present in order for PP3V42_G3H to flow to the onewire circuit so that the circuitry that allows the charger to communicate with the SMC will turn on.  .
definitions.CHGR_ACOK: What is CHGR_ACOK? This is identical to SMC_BC_ACOK. This will come out of the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging chip when CHGR_ACIN & CHGR_DCIN are present, and is necessary for the onewire circuit to begin working. On most Macbooks, CHGR_ACOK needs to be present in order for PP3V42_G3H to flow to the onewire circuit so that the circuitry that allows the charger to communicate with the SMC will turn on.  .
definitions.CHGR_ACIN: What is CHGR_ACIN? CHGR_ACIN is a signal that is created by a voltage divider between the charger and ground that goes into the ISL6258, ISL6259, ISL9239, or ISL9240 chip that creates PPBUS_G3H. It is necessary for SMC_BC_ACOK & CHGR_ACOK to be present so that the onewire circuit is told to turn on & allow the SMC to speak to the charger..
definitions.C7020: What is C7020? Capacitor between current sense lines on ISL6259 chip for charger current sensing, you should measure around 20.02 ohms across this. Often when the resistance across this capacitor is higher it is because one of the current sense resistors going to the ISL6259 chip has failed. When current sensing resistors between the shunt resistor and the ISL6259 power IC have failed the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being drawn from the charger, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing as much power from the charger as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H, quarter fan spin, boot looping, or battery not charging..
definitions.CHGR_CSI_N: What is CHGR_CSI_N? CHGR_CSI_N is one of the current sense lines for the charger. Resistance between CHGR_CSI_N and CHGR_CSI_P should be the resistance should be the total series resistance of the current sense resistors in the circuit, usually about 20.02 ohms.
definitions.CHGR_CSI_P: What is CHGR_CSI_P? CHGR_CSI_P is one of the current sense lines for the charger. Resistance between CHGR_CSI_P and CHGR_CSI_N should be the resistance should be the total series resistance of the current sense resistors in the circuit, usually about 20.02 ohms.
definitions.CHGR_DCIN: What is CHGR_DCIN? CHGR_DCIN comes directly from charger into ISL6258 or ISL6259, the resistor before it can be blown when there are surges. Should be checked when PPBUS_G3H is missing.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.ISL6259: What is ISL6259? This is a charging chip for Macbook motherboards from 2010 through 2015.
definitions.PP3V3_S5_REG: What is PP3V3_S5_REG? PP3V3_S5_REG is a 3.3v power rail present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state. .
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.SMC_PM_G2_EN: What is SMC_PM_G2_EN? SMC_PM_G2_EN is a signal that comes from the SMC that is a prerequsite for all of the enable signals for the S5 rails to come on, such as P3V3S5_EN. S5 rails will not come on if SMC_PM_G2_EN is not coming..
definitions.PP5V_S5_LDO: What is PP5V_S5_LDO? PP5V_S5_LDO is a 5v rail present when the machine is in a S5 soft off state. .

threads.title: [FUBAR] LB <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> B no green or orange light (needs SMC)
threads.message: If <SIGNAL>CHGR_ACIN</SIGNAL> is present and <SIGNAL>CHGR_DCIN</SIGNAL> is present and the resistance between pins 27/28 and pins 17/18 adds up to what the sense resistors' sum is, I would say time to replace <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>. Stay away from SI7149DP that thing is always fine, you can dip it in battery acid coca cola cat piss and beer and light it on fire and it will still work!

threads.message: the chip has more load on it than anything else since <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> powers the entire machine, and it also has to deal with knockoff chargers and ripple on <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> as well as its own issues when there's water.

threads.title: [FUBAR] LB <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> B no green or orange light (needs SMC)
threads.message:
Dude that is fucking scary. You need one strand of wire for this!!! Why do you think they call it the onewire circuit :p 

You have 3.36v on pin 5, but what about pin 4? Is it outputting voltage now?

<CHIP>U6901</CHIP> is a logic gate that, when <SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK</SIGNAL> is present, will allow <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> to pass to output. The idea here is that it will power <CHIP>U6900</CHIP> which allows the charger to talk to the SMC if the <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP>/<CHIP>U7000</CHIP> says that it is ok for it to. So follow to the next logical step - is <CHIP>U6900</CHIP> getting 3.4v? Is <CHIP>U6901</CHIP> shooting out 3.4v for <CHIP>U6900</CHIP>? If not, why?

If your PPDCIN is 18.5V but <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is only 4.57V there is maybe something pulling it down! YES
Probe with your fingers if something is getting hot.
Desolder F7040 and measure the voltage on pad1 of F7040
Are you able to inject 12V to <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> with an external power source?

threads.title: [FUBAR] LB <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> B no green or orange light (needs SMC)
threads.message: <TRANSISTOR>Q7030</TRANSISTOR>/<TRANSISTOR>Q7035</TRANSISTOR> killed the isl which then killed the <TRANSISTOR>Q7030</TRANSISTOR>/<TRANSISTOR>Q7035</TRANSISTOR>. replace them all in one foul swoop and make sure your soldering is correct. This video sucks, but gets the point across. [url]https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JTS0rkx_JAQ[/url]

threads.title: [FUBAR] LB <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> B no green or orange light (needs SMC)
threads.message: Resistor measures good, pin 1 on <CHIP>U7840</CHIP> is 3.4v,  <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> is 3.4v on pin 13 of <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>.  I have no visible signs of damage around the <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> but would you recommend replacing <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> anyway? Is there some way to test if it is good?

threads.title: [FUBAR] LB <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> B no green or orange light (needs SMC)
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> creates <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> by telling <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> on pin 13 to turn on <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>. Do you have <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>? If you do, pin 13 can go away. 

Check for a short to ground on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>. If no short to ground, remove <TRANSISTOR>Q7221</TRANSISTOR> and tell me if <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> comes up.

threads.title: [FUBAR] LB <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> B no green or orange light (needs SMC)
threads.message: I do not have <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> it measures 2.2v-3.8v fluctuating. Removed <TRANSISTOR>Q7221</TRANSISTOR> and no change

threads.title: [FUBAR] LB <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> B no green or orange light (needs SMC)
threads.message: <TRANSISTOR>Q7221</TRANSISTOR> is related to a different rail. If <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> is not fluctuating, but <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> is fluctuating, it's a safe bet your issue is either with <CHIP>U7200</CHIP>(likely) or <CHIP>U7840</CHIP>(less likely, but still possible). You have green light to replace <CHIP>U7200</CHIP>! Bonus points if you don't burn the fan or speaker connector.

Ok, screwed that up. <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> in diode mode measures .023v not fluctuating, <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5_LDO</SIGNAL> is fluctuating at .361-.4v in diode mode so it looks like they are shorted to ground.
When I check these points on a working board in diode mode i get OL

threads.title: [FUBAR] LB <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> B no green or orange light (needs SMC)
threads.message:
1) 0.36 to 0.4v in diode mode is not shorted to ground
2) Please for the love of god tell me you are not making diode mode measurements with power going through the board
3) I asked if <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> voltage is fluctuating. Measure voltage. Is it steady or does it move?

threads.title: [FUBAR] LB <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> B no green or orange light (needs SMC)
threads.message:
Ok, they are not shorted, and <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> is fluctuating in mv, and yes i am an idiot!
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5_LDO</SIGNAL> = .53v
<SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> = .421v

threads.title: [FUBAR] LB <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> B no green or orange light (needs SMC)
threads.message:
So we're clear, those are DC voltage measurements, and not diode mode measurements, right?

If so, <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> is too low, which points to an SMC issue, <CHIP>U7840</CHIP> pulling it down, or <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> pulling it down. At this point since you've already replaced <CHIP>U7200</CHIP>, my guess is bad SMC.

threads.title: [FUBAR] LB <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> B no green or orange light (needs SMC)
threads.message:
no, I had power unplugged and checked in diode mode for the .53v and the .421v. I then plugged in power and measured dc voltage on <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> and got a very low mv on probe point 1006.
Could be possible that the <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> I replaced was bad? There was very little liquid spill on the machine, I pulled the <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> off a donor board from china. I feel like I might be missing something from my inexperience , that maybe effecting diagnosis. Having g3hot and the 12v rail just seems like the problem might be the technician. :)
The <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5_LDO</SIGNAL> with power plugged in, checked at probe point 650 reads from dc voltage of 2.8v to 3.6v fluctuating rapidly and at <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> its basically nothing

threads.title: [FUBAR] LB <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> B no green or orange light (needs SMC)
threads.message:
I can only guess that <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> is 0v because you've never posted a real number. :(

Anything is possible, but <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> being 0v is your main issue here. That should be at 3.4v immediately. My guess here is SMC if <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> is present as well as <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>. You need <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> to create <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> and get the ball rolling with everything else.

threads.title: [FUBAR] LB <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> B no green or orange light (needs SMC)
threads.message:
Yes, i have <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> 3.4v. so we basically have a dead SMC. Oh well one for the donor pile.  You make it look so easy on your videos! Thanks for your patience.
Do you have a source for the isight connectors on the 2013 and 2014 15" macbook pros?

threads.title: [FUBAR] LB <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> B no green or orange light (needs SMC)
threads.message: The source for connectors like that are scrap boards from your pile or China. Connector is the same on 13" boards.

threads.title: [FUBAR] LB <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> B no green or orange light (needs SMC)
threads.message: Ok, thanks again for all your help.

threads.title: [FUBAR] LB <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> B no green or orange light (needs SMC)
threads.message: how do we close this topic?

threads.title: [FUBAR] LB <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> B no green or orange light (needs SMC)
threads.message:
Ok, louis I am responding to your video today on success.
My daughter was able to micro solder on this board. (she has never done that before)
We were able to get green light on the charger by running a wire to fix the one wire circuit. (first wire was hideous, but the second one was much nicer) Have never done that before. 
We where able to get the 12v circuit running.
Successfully soldered the <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP> (took three tries:o)
We where not able to get the 5v up because of the SMC, however It was a great success for us at least because we are learning how to problem solve these boards.

I used to send all my boards to your favorite company (L2 Computer) :o I sent them enough that I was getting them at $180
Although I didn't get this board to work, I didn't send it to them either. Another success!
Eventually, We will learn more and have even greater success

Thanks for all you guys are doing!

threads.title: [FUBAR] LB <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> B no green or orange light (needs SMC)
threads.message: If your daughter can't replace the SMC then fire her :p ;)
